definition: impractical
literal-minded/pedantic/doctrinaire/longwinded/circuitous
to distance oneself from (classical)
far/distant/remote/(intensifier in a comparison) by far/much (lower etc)
high sounding and impractical/high flown nonsense

lit. Ying writes a letter and Yan reads it/fig. to misinterpret the original meaning/to pile up errors/refers to the letter from capital 郢[Ying3] of 楚[Chu3] in which the inadvertent words "hold up the candle" are mistaken by the minister of 燕[Yan1] as "promote the wise"
unrealistic/pedantic and impractical
pedantic and stubborn
stupid/impractical
to revere the past and despise the present (idiom)
dispensing praise or blame with a single word (idiom)/concise and powerful style
prejudiced/narrow-minded
that being the case/then/in that case
rash/hasty
dead letter/rule no longer in force/empty formality
the way of former kings
grandiose but impractical (idiom)/large but of no real use
Confucian
Grand Scribe, the title by which Sima Qian 司馬遷|司马迁[Si1 ma3 Qian1] refers to himself in Records of the Historian 史記|史记[Shi3 ji4]
progress seems like regress (the Book of Dao 道德經|道德经[Dao4 de2 jing1], Chpt. 41)
